titlestmt.titleproper: Preliminary Inventory to the William Yandell Elliott papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff; machine-readable finding aid created by Michael C. Conkin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-07-24T12:41-0700

change.item: Descriptions of reformatted audiovisual items updated
Revised to update encoding and add unitid
PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::William Yandell Elliott Papers)//EN" "elliott.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16)

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, speeches, research notes, clippings, and printed matter relating to American national security and defense, American politics and foreign relations, American military-industrial relations, and American national labor policy.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copies of all sound recordings in this collection are available. For access to any video recordings or motion picture film in this collection, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], William Yandell Elliott papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: American political scientist; staff director, House Select Committee on Foreign Affairs, 1947-1949; member, planning board, National Security Council, 1953-1957; consultant to the secretary of state, 1958-1970.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1977, with increments received in 1988 and 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A talk by Elliott at a seminar, "Contemporary Political Theory," recorded as both sound recordings and a transcript. The transcript starts approximately 4 minutes into the speech.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, speeches and writings, memoranda, and reports relating to William Y. Elliott's government service and career at Harvard University, U.S. domestic and foreign policy, and inter-war and post-war Europe.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copies of all sound recordings in this collection are available for immediate access.

did.unittitle: Dictation of letters to Professor Nelson and Henry Kissinger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. Side 1 is a letter to Professor Nelson, Waterloo University, for Roger Swauson. He gives his opinions on students/scholars. Side 2 is a letter to Henry Kissinger regarding foreign affairs. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of a letter to Rosemary Woods

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a letter to Nixon's secretary, Rosemary Woods. Elliott offers his insights into important elements of the presidential campaign. Included are the possibility of the House deciding the election, the impact of Wallace, Southeast Asia, and past campaigns. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of a letter to President Nixon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. On side 1, Elliot dictates a letter to President Nixon regarding the Black Power movement. He is critical of actions on academic campuses, describing them as armed invasions. He says they want to live on the backs of other, calling it a reversal of slavery. On side 2, Elliot talks about communism and detente. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of a recommendation letter for Professor Cromwell to the Executive Secretary of NATO and letter to Winifred Lewis
Dictation of letters to Samuel Huntington and Mr. H. Edward English

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The letter to Samuel Huntington concerns a summer job; that to Mr. H. Edward English, Carleton University, regards a conference on December 13-16. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Captain Havan B. Page regarding the conference at Little Boston; Dr. Julian K. Knipp, Dean at Tufts, regarding faculty for political science; Mr. and Mrs. James Dickey regarding poetry and round table; Gloria Barion regarding apt. with Moley and Lindly; and the Gulf Oil Corporation regarding returned radio. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of letters to Marguerite Bouvard and Cecil Crobb

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. The letter to Mrs. Marguerite Bouvard concerns a recommendation for her work; the letter to Cecil Crobb, Louisiana State University, concerns Col. Gleb. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of a letter to Clayton D. Ford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The letter concerns his schedule with the Nixon administration and not being able to meet with Mr. Ford. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Sound recording of William Elliott explaining the moral basis for American foreign policy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Elliott discusses the intersection of morals and politics. Included in this are discussions of force, Marx, communism, domestic policies (slavery, busing, etc.), and detente with the Soviet Union. Recorded on two Soundwriter discs

did.unittitle: Dictation of a letter to Francis Wilcox

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dictation of a letter to Francis Wilcox, Dean of SAIS at John Hopkins, regarding Canadian studies and a conference at Carlton. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. Letter to Ward Elliot regarding family and professional issues, letter to Barry Farrell regarding US-Canadian Center at SAIS. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of a letter to Mrs. Norman Robertson

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Year of recording is unknown. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of letters to Professor Khadum and Richard Fenno

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Year of recording is unknown. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of letters to Marguerite Hildebrand, Mrs. Robertson, Randall Ridley, Jesse Wills, Charles Ragland, and Mrs. Alex Stevenson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. The letter to Hildebrand concerns her job; the one to Mrs. Robertson is an addendum to a previous letter clarifying a comment about Rome; the letter to Ridley concerns Ridley's work, Elliot's retirement and finances, and son Ward's wedding; the letter to Wills concerns the SDS and campus community opinions, ROTC, a donation to the archives, and videotapes; the letter to Ragland concerns a wedding, a death, and a visit to Elliott's farm; the letter to Stevenson concerns Mr. Stevenson's death. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of letters to David Packard, Don K. Price, James T. Murray

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. The letter to Packard concerns the farm and California; that to Price is one of "joy and cheer;" the letter to Murray concerns essays. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of a letter to Miss Schurr of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. Letter concerning documents of his wife's qualifications to receive insurance annuity upon Elliott's death. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of letters to Miss Yudae and Miss Newcomb

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter to Yudae concerns income tax and the TIAA annuity. For part 2 of Newcomb letter, see Dictation of letters to Lincoln Gordon and Miss Newcomb. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of letters to Lincoln Gordon and Miss Newcomb

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The letter to Gordon concerns possible presidential administrations following the 1968 election; that to Newcomb is a continuation of his thoughts on totalitarianism (for part 1, see Dictation of letters to Miss Yudae and Miss Newcomb. Recorded on a Soundwriter disc

did.unittitle: Dictation of letter and memo concerning the Business Council

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Year of recording is unknown. The letter contains W.Y. Elliott's suggestions to the Business Council on the future handling of the takeover of the forces of anarchy and rebellion in the United States, the control of the media of mass communications, the influencing of opinion, and the intimidation of the electorate. Recorded on four Soudwriter discs

did.unittitle: Sound recording of Elliott describing his objectives in regard to the Principia Public Affairs Conference

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Elliott discusses the fight against communism, describing the differences between he Soviet Union and communist China. While he believes their objectives are the same, he says they differ in various areas. In the process, topics he covers are Vietnam, Cuba, nuclear weapons, economics, trade with mutual partners, currencies, commodities, culture/the arts, and the Peace Corps. Recorded on five Soundwriter discs

did.unittitle: Rest of increment not yet described

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes one folder (in box 196) of undated writings related to American foreign policy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly security-classified records of the U.S. government, released in full or in part. Arranged chronologically by date of release by Hoover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declassified copy of a 15 November 1950 report from Nitze to Marshall with a subject of "Legislative Prospect."
